extracted_key_facts: The Polisario threatened to resume hostilities with Morocco if it did not cease building a road connecting Morocco to Senegal through the buffer zone in 2016.
Both Morocco and the Polisario mobilized forces to their sides of the ceasefire line until Morocco withdrew in February 2017 and the Polisario did likewise in April 2017.
The long-time Polisario leader, Mohammed Abdelaziz, died on 31st May 2016, potentially impacting conflict dynamics.
MINURSO was established to monitor the ceasefire between Morocco and the Polisario, among other objectives.

Morocco demanded the United Nations (UN) to withdraw all its civilian personnel from Western Sahara within 72 hours in March 2016 after UNSG Ban Ki Moon described the situation in Western Sahara as an ‘occupation’.
Tensions between the UN and Morocco were amplified by Morocco’s plan to build a road connecting Morocco to Senegal through the 'buffer zone' established in 1991 to maintain the ceasefire.
The Popular Front for Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro (Polisario) was formed in 1973 as a movement requesting independence of Spanish Sahara.
MINURSO's mandate was renewed by the UN Security Council (UNSC) on the condition that the mission return to full functionality within 90 days in April 2016.
The UN has been active in Western Sahara since 1986.
MINURSO is regarded as a failure by some because it was unable to hold a referendum on the independence of Western Sahara.
MINURSO was deployed during the period of the post-Cold War expansion of UN peacekeeping.
The thesis focuses on the period of 1988 to 2007, starting with the UN settlement plan and ending with the presentation of plans by Morocco and the Polisario.
Mohammed Abdelaziz led the Polisario as Secretary-General since 1976.
The long-term aim of the MINURSO mission was to hold a self-determination referendum.

After Morocco and the Polisario both accepted the UN peace-plan on 30th August 1988, the UN began to plan the peace-operation and in April 1991 deployed the UN peacekeeping mission in the Western Sahara, known by its French acronym MINURSO.

Morocco launched an offensive against the Polisario in the Polisario-controlled Western Sahara (SADR) in late August to early September 1991, targeting Tifariti and Bir Lahlou before the ceasefire officially came into effect.
MINURSO was deployed in the territory to observe the ceasefire in September 1991.
As of January 1996, there were 258 ceasefire violations noted by the UNSG, with 232 committed by the Moroccan army.
